Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

description.narrative: (Jamaica): With FY 2022 funds, USAID will help address economic disparities and support inclusion of marginalized, vulnerable populations in the workforce. USAID's Support for Vulnerable Populations activity will support pre-employment and employability programs for those disproportionately impacted by HIV. Assistance will help improve employability and entrepreneurial skills so that the target population can find and retain jobs or create their own livelihood activity, which will support adherence to treatment. This activity will provide a link to a holistic continuum of services, including psychosocial support, mentorship, and after-job-placement support. Job training and opportunities will be in both formal and informal settings and may include market driven skills training; mock interview forums; and targeted programs that support entrepreneurship skills, including access to credit, financial management, and marketing skills.

description.narrative: Funded under the Caribbean Basin Security Initiative (CBSI), the multiyear Community Violence Prevention (CVP) project in Jamaica is designed to support families to prevent youth violence and to develop pathway programs for youth at risk of violence. DI is strengthening existing USAID and Government of Jamaica endeavors and creating new opportunities for promoting community-based partnerships to prevent youth violence and support citizen security. DIs interventions prioritize leveraging and coordinating existing community violence prevention resources in Jamaica, supporting local initiatives and strengths using cutting-edge social and behavior science approaches, and encouraging Jamaican-led, Jamaican-owned activities. Using a Positive Youth Development approach, CVP focuses on interventions with youthwho are most susceptible to becoming involved in criminality and violenceand their families to build emotional resilience, invaluable life skills, and economic opportunities. In addition, by drawing on innovative social and behavioral science, CVP supports families, youth, and communities to take simple, effective actions for lasting behavior change. The CVP project directly supports USAID in creating successful interventions targeting youth crime and violence prevention and works to enhance institutions effective responses to crime and violence in Jamaica.

title.narrative: Strengthening Energy Sector Resilience in Jamaica

description.narrative: (Jamaica): Energy disruption is a major impediment to rapid recovery in the aftermath of a natural disaster. To bolster current efforts to enhance Jamaica's capacity to mitigate the effects of natural disasters, USAID will support initiatives to improve energy sector resilience through the use of renewable energy and develop partnerships with small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to promote the adoption of distributed renewable energy, enhance resilience, and reduce grid disruptions. Illustrative activities include: 1) development of outreach materials focused on SMEs; 2) coordination with business associations to identify members who are interested in distributed renewable energy and conduct outreach; 3) identification of businesses in these sector(s) interested in acquiring solar and battery systems and facilitating deals with investor partners; and 4) engagement of the financial sector on the perceived risks and opportunities of lending for solar systems and financial products available to support SME adoption...While many emergency facilities have back-up diesel generators, their length of service depends upon fuel storage and resupply, where solar systems with batteries can operate indefinitely, making them resilient under the harsh weather conditions that have been seen in some Caribbean countries in recent years. In partnership with the GoJ and the private sector, USAID will identify and plan a new solar and battery system for a critical emergency facility based on the potential for distributed solar energy systems with batteries to reduce electricity costs by up to 30 percent, thereby allowing an emergency facility to be completely or partially grid-independent...USAID will document lessons learned on the development of distributed renewable energy for dissemination and replicability in other Caribbean countries..

description.narrative: The UWI will manage health connect Jamaica to contribute to jamaica's 90-90-90 targets. this will be done by implementing HIV prevention, care and treatment support services working through a private sector network of providers and in partnership with the public sector laboratory and pharmacy services. uwi will support adult prevention, care & treatment activities that will do the following: - identify remaining numbers of undiagnosed individuals social network strategies and services by aggressively promoting and rolling out partner referral and index testing - identify those individuals diagnosed with hiv prior but not on art - link diagnosed individuals to hiv care and treatment for early art initiation - return plhiv lost to follow-up to treatment services, - ensure adherence and retention in services to achieve viral suppression. uwi will roll out adolescent care & treatment interventions that addresses the gaps in the quantity and quality of adolescent focused hiv treatment services, with a key focus on care & treatment services for the high prevalence populations identified in the nsp. this will expand the access points for clinician intervention for adolescent-specific service delivery thereby improving retention and viral load access. the activity will support peer-led adherence clubs that have been proven to increase adherence to antiretroviral drugs.

Develop and conduct needs assessments, baseline studies, targeted evaluations, special studies or other information-gathering efforts specifically for the design, monitoring and evaluation of USG-funded programs. This sub-element may also include developing and disseminating best practices and lessons learned, testing demonstration and/or pilot models, or the preparation of strategic plans and other short-term programming tasks. Note: All such activities that are carried out by partners as an integral part of their monitoring and evaluation efforts for programs funded under other sub-elements should be included within those sub-elements.

(State Western Hemisphere Regional): .USAID recognizes that strong monitoring, evaluation, and learning (MEL) practices are critical to improving outcomes in youth violence prevention activities. Through the Jamaica Monitoring Evaluation and Learning (JAMEL) support for the CBSI activity, USAID will provide dedicated support to develop the MEL capacity of local government and NGOs that work to prevent youth crime and violence in Jamaica. USAID will provide technical assistance on how to develop MEL plans, identify suitable indicators and set targets, institute monitoring protocols, and adapt activity implementation based on monitoring data. The activity will also facilitate annual assessments to inform the Mission's and CBSI's learning agendas for youth crime and violence programming..

The USAID Supporting Victims of Violence Activity will strengthen awareness of and access to trauma-informed services for survivors, witnesses, and perpetrators of violence, leading to shifts in attitudes and increased resilience to the risk factors faced by youth, families, and communities that make them susceptible to crime and violence. Specifically, the activity will strengthen the capacity of the Government of Jamaica (GOJ), non-governmental organizations (NGOs), and civil society organizations (CSOs) to provide quality support services and foster coordination through collective action initiatives (CAIs) in hotspot communities that identify, prevent, and respond to violence.

title.narrative: Jamaica Rural Economy and Ecosystems Adapting to Climate Change (JA-REEACH)

description.narrative: (Jamaica): Over $1.1 million dollars will be directly attributed to climate change adaptation interventions in Jamaica through the Jamaica Rural Economy and Ecosystems Adapting to Climate Change (JA-REEACH) activity. JA-REEACH is a continuation of USAID's investments to date to protect rural lives, livelihoods and ecosystems in targeted communities affected by climate change through interventions that drive adaptation and build resilience. Farmers will be equipped with skills needed to adapt to drought and increased precipitation variability through more efficient water use systems. Communities, higher education institutions and government agencies will benefit from improved disaster risk reduction through capacity building and training. An institutional capacity assessment will assess local organizations on their ability and readiness to implement USAID-funded climate change activities in the future. An extension of the cooperative agreement to end FY 2015 is currently underway. (IM 532-A-00-10-00005-00, $1,117,959 focussed GCC-AD)

description.narrative: Assist special populations which may be vulnerable or at-risk on a temporary or chronic basis whose needs are not addressed under emergency humanitarian assistance or other programs. These include groups such as the disabled; orphans, children and at-risk youth; victims of trafficking; victims of gender-based violence; refugees, returnees, ethnic minorities, internally displaced or other socially excluded groups; the elderly; and female heads of household. Depending on circumstances, services may intend to protect groups; mitigate adverse conditions they face, or to remove barriers to help integrate them into society. Components may include measures to increase the capacity of local service and advocacy NGOs and/or professional social workers; to establish public/private service delivery partnerships as well as family and community focused service models; to establish effective referral networks; to develop appropriate service protocols and methods for screening prospective recipients; or to improve public understanding and sensitivity to the needs of the vulnerable. While services provided should not exclude victims of trafficking in persons, programs designed specifically for this group fall under the Peace and Security Objective under the Transnational Crime Area and the Trafficking in Persons and Migrant Smuggling Element.

description.narrative: Improve the capacity and sustainability of civil and criminal justice sector actors and institutions, enhance coordination amongst them, develop citizen demand for an effective and accountable justice system, and develop associations to advocate for all citizens. Justice sector actors and institutions include: police, border security, prosecutors, forensics experts, judges, court personnel, public defenders, corrections personnel, private bar, law schools, legal professional associations, and training institutions for each of them. Work towards an equitable justice system by ensuring equality before the law, fair trial standards, and other elements of procedural fairness. Ensure more equitable access to justice through innovations within and beyond the state system and through improvements in the quality and quantity of justice services, with a particular focus on women, youth, the poor, and other marginalized or vulnerable groups. Programs primarily focused on trafficking in persons or migrant smuggling should be included in element 5.3 under the Transnational Crime area in the Peace and Security Objective.

description.narrative: Collaborate to Prosper is a microenterprise development programme designed to enable Jamaican enterprises in two existing products, and one potential service, segments to upgrade their operations, improve their profitability and, ultimately, produce for exports. The areas of focus are: Ornamental Fish in inner city, underserved communities; Specialty Crops in rural communities; and Innovation for Exports which will, through a challenge approach, support young people with commercialisable ideas to bring them to market.

Sustain the productivity of the agricultural sector through investments that foster increasing returns to land, labor, and capital. Targeted interventions to male and female producers provide improvements in technology and management practices, expanded access to markets and credit, increased organizational and market efficiency, and restoration and protection of resiliency in production and livelihood systems.

Illustrative activities include the following: public sector reform and public management; strategic planning, policy, and budget formulation; building ministry capacity; civilian and civic capacity building; formal oversight (legislative, fiscal, human rights); and informal oversight (civil society watchdog groups).

title.narrative: CBSI-Jamaica-ESF-Transitional Living Program for Children in State Care

description.narrative: (State Western Hemisphere Regional): USAID implements programs in the Caribbean that focus on communities where youth are at risk of engaging in crime and violence. This includes transitioning youth who have grown up in state care facilities and have reached the age of 18 and have no support system in place. Support will include the construction of transitional living facilities for children who will leave state care at the age of 18. USAID will also assist these youth with life skills and technical training, apprenticeship and job placement programs. USAID will build the capacity of the Child Development Agency through the training of care workers in psycho-social skills to interact with this vulnerable group. Programs working with the most at-risk youth to deter them from crime and violence contribute towards strengthening Caribbean and U.S. national security and advancing the safety of our citizens.

title.narrative: CBSI-Jamaica-ESF-Combatting Corruption and Strengthening Integrity in Jamaica

description.narrative: (State Western Hemisphere Regional): USAID's anti-corruption activity continues to support improvements in Jamaica's governance landscape and capacity for preventing, detecting, combatting, and punishing corruption. Anti-corruption programming contributes towards strengthening Caribbean and U.S. national security and advancing the safety of our citizens. The activity seeks to build and strengthen the capacity of government partners in areas of good governance, accountability, and law enforcement - key contributions to the CBSI pillar supporting Social Justice. With FY 2017 funding, USAID will continue to train judges, police officers, and prosecutors to apply existing laws to combat corruption. The activity will also support the newly formed Integrity Commission with staff training and providing legal advice to citizens who are victims of corruption and seeking redress, and/or who are witnesses of corruption.

title.narrative: "A New Path": Promoting a Healthy Environment and Productive Alternatives for Juvenile Remandees and Offenders in Jamaica [CBSI]

description.narrative: The "New Path" activity directly supports USAID Jamaica's objective of reducing citizen vulnerability while improving the security of communities and at-risk youth. It also supports the CBSI pillar of promoting social justice through crime prevention activities in targeted communities, with increased educational, economic and social opportunities for at-risk youth and other vulnerable populations. Interventions include providing skills, psychosocial support, and business training that give youth economic opportunities and social skills, which make them less likely to re-offend and commit crimes; thus, improving citizen security. USAID will build the capacity of the Department of Correctional Services and the Ministry of National Security to engage with vulnerable groups through sensitivity training and study tours of similar facilities in other countries.

(Jamaica): USAID/Jamaica will use FY 2017 funds to transition community-based activities that increase the capacity of communities and local governance systems to adapt to droughts, floods, and hurricanes, to GOJ and civil society actors. Projects initiated by USAID/Jamaica in this area are based on the premise that prevention ahead of a disaster saves lives, and are vastly more cost efficient compared to post-disaster response. USAID helps the Jamaican government to integrate disaster risk reduction into planning and improve policies that improve coordination. Community members are trained in improved planning, disaster risks and response, and building social cohesion while promoting resilient livelihoods. By consolidating activities and formulating a comprehensive exit strategy, this investment will sustain gains made in disaster risk reduction, community resilience and improved planning practices, which increase stability and security in Jamaica.

description.narrative: (State Western Hemisphere Regional): With a homicide rate of nearly 49 per 100,000 people, Jamaica's violent crime rate has resulted in its regular inclusion in the list of top ten countries with the highest murder rates in the world. Successive governments have been unable to effectively address crime and violence at the community level, with local civil society organizations (CSOs) and parts of the private sector attempting to fill the gap. However, most Jamaican CSOs involved in crime and violence prevention lack the technical capacity and knowledge to implement targeted, successful programs, and rely on strategies that target the general population. In order to achieve long-term impact, USAID will strengthen select CSOs that work to advance youth crime and violence prevention in hot spot communities and focus on youth at the highest risk of recruitment into gangs and other criminal activities. USAID programming will help these organizations become more effective actors in providing sustainable services that reduce youth crime and violence in Jamaica; coordinate crime prevention interventions and mobilize financial resources to prevent crime with the private sector; and advance state-run interventions that improve the institutional effectiveness for local actors working on crime and violence prevention. USAID will coordinate closely with the Government of Jamaica, in particular the Ministry of National Security, which has intensified its crime prevention efforts to ensure that programs are directly aligned with GOJ strategic objectives. Programming will include grants for direct technical assistance and piloting of initiatives to select state and non-state actors to develop tools to identify those most at-risk, strengthen coordination of evidence-based, targeted secondary crime prevention interventions, and pilot secondary crime prevention initiatives at the community level.

description.narrative: Improve sustainability of a productive and clean environment by reducing risks to the health of the workforce and the population in general, communities, and ecosystems from environmental pollution and other environmental risks associated with industrial and agricultural production, urbanization, energy use, transport, and other human activity.

COMET combines the expertise of representatives from the Jamaican government and local and international NGOs to reduce crime and violence and strengthen economic competitiveness in the countrys inner cities. COMET aims to strengthen the capacity of the Jamaica Constabulary Force (JCF), or police, to conduct law enforcement throughout the country.

A four-year project to provide training, technical assistance and commodity support to assist the Ministry of Education in improving primary school student performance in reading and mathematics, to strengthen accountability in the primary education system through the use of measurement tools and the establishment of standards, and to build regional capacity for school management oversight. The project aimed at increasing the accountability of principals, students, parents and teachers in the improvement of student performance in reading and mathematics in the early grades (1-3). Also, it aimed at improving the capacity of the MOE, the Regional Education Authorities, the Jamaica Teaching Council and the National Education Inspectorate to monitor school management, and the National Education Trust to increase public and private contributions. The project utilized accountability mechanisms that set goals and held principals, teachers, parents and students responsible for results.

title.narrative: Promote, Renew, Invigorate,Develop and Energize the Economic Environment (PRIDE)

description.narrative: The goal of PRIDE Jamaica is to support the Government of Jamaica (GOJ) and other key stakeholders to reduce barriers and support a positive economic enabling environment. PRIDE Jamaica works with stakeholders in the private and public sectors to promote free market economic policies and streamline government regulations, processes and practices to improve Jamaicas competitive position in the international market as a desirable place to do business. Working with public-private partnerships and other donors, PRIDE Jamaica leverages resources to establish stakeholder support and maximize project impact.

Improve the ability of the USG, host countries and other partners to prepare for and mitigate the effects of disasters, including both natural disasters and complex emergencies, taking into account the differences in men and womens freedom of movement and access to information. Activities under this component include any efforts to enhance the capacities of the USG (in Washington and in the field), humanitarian assistance providers, national host-country authorities, and local communities to engage in disaster reduction and response activities. Activities consist of standardized and coordinated assessments, monitoring, information sharing, data and situational analysis, joint planning; enhancement of coping mechanisms, including the capacity to address adaptation to constantly changing situations on the ground including climate variability and climate change.
